awd_titl_txt: Building a Pathway for CS Principles Teachers:  A Two-course Sequence for Secondary Education Mathematics Pre-service Teachers
awd_abstract_narration:
The University of Alabama Tuscaloosa proposes to develop a new model for preparing preservice teachers to realize the CSforAll goal of scaling computer science (CS) education to tens of thousands of schools.  The project will expand an existing research-practitioner partnership (RPP) to support preservice Secondary Mathematics (SEMA) students with coursework that will prepare them to offer AP Computer Science Principles (CSP) at their future school. Many current Professional Development (PD) efforts for CS education focus on existing in-service teachers, but the future growth will also need to consider the preparation of preservice Education majors who will develop content and pedagogical CS knowledge through exposure to CSP topics.
 
The proposed work advances a course sequence and associated activities that form a pathway for preservice educators who do not have deep pre-existing CS content knowledge. The sequence includes an existing CSP course currently taken by all SEMA students, and a new, second course for those students with an interest in teaching CSP in addition to mathematics. This second course will introduce students to topics related to equity in CS education, overview various K-12 CS standards (including the newly developed Alabama K-12 CS standards), explore connections to mathematics with computational thinking practices and CS content knowledge, consider various nuances of Advanced Placement (AP) CSP curricula endorsed by the College Board, and establish a deeper understanding of the AP CSP Big Ideas and Learning Objectives. Students will also participate in a teaching practicum and serve as student teachers at the local high schools of RPP members. They will also have the opportunity to attend a College Board CSP AP Summer Institute and a conference focused on CS education. The courses will be externally evaluated. In addition, the researchers and practitioners within the RPP will develop and explore a set of research questions related to the interest and self-efficacy of SEMA students as they prepare to become CSP teachers. These new teachers will be the catalyst for broadening the participation of computing at high schools that heretofore have not established a CS course.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: Computer Science for All (CS for All)
EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
This project's intellectual merit (IM) proposed to collect data and analyze knowledge development of secondary math teacher candidates (TCs) during the implementation of a two-course sequence for computer science principles (CSP). The IM focused on: (1) support the development of CS endorsement pathways across the nation within existing teacher preparation programs (TPPs), (2) present empirical evidence of the impact of such pathways on TCs knowledge domains of the Technological Pedagogical and Content Knowledge (TPACK) framework, (3) understand the complexities of a statewide rollout of a non-major teaching endorsement embedded within existing program designs, and (4) document the impact of a successful local curriculum implemented across multiple stakeholders that involve deep interaction with partners who are existing K-12 CS educators.

The IM results were a successful, state approved, pathway leading to a state issued CSP course-specific add-on teaching credential. Graduates of our two-course sequence who obtain the state issued CSP permit have the immediate ability to teach advanced placement (AP) CSP in schools using a College Board endorsed curriculum. TCs' TPACK and sub-domains of knowledge showed statistically significant gains with N=30 participants. Further, the IM created knowledge about navigating teacher certification with add-on credentials that bypassed the need for a CS major to become CS teacher certified. Lastly, the successful model led to a statewide partnership with the state department of education and five other higher education institutions. The project produced four scholarly publications with a fifth empirical journal paper in development.

The project's broader impacts (BI) include opportunities for up to 13,500 high school students to have the ability to enroll and complete AP CSP from an endorsed teacher. Further, the project has the potential to impact up to an additional 16,000 students who may enroll in other CS courses taught by fully endorsed CS teachers. Consistent with past NSF projects in Alabama, a focus on broadening the participation opportunities for underrepresented student populations was a core project value, with participation recruitment efforts focused on selecting future educators who may serve in school districts with high-minority enrollment. Furthermore, TCs participating in the program also understand the unique opportunities to promote diversity, equity, and inclusiveness in their future CS classrooms. Beyond the life of the project and the subsequent statewide rollout across TPPs, there is a potential to credential more than 200 endorsed CS teachers statewide through the implementation of the project curriculum in the immediate five years after the grant ends. By producing secondary TCs with a state-approved pathway to a CS credential within their existing secondary content discipline certification program (e.g., mathematics, science, social studies), the project has the potential to realize transformative statewide impact.

The broader impacts (to date) are estimated to have 50% of the participants teaching either one or more CS courses each academic year, as well as using CS concepts in the teaching of mathematics. It is estimated that at least 2000 students have learned from participants in a CS course offered by the TCs who participated in our project and more students received benefits in mathematics classrooms using CS concepts for teaching mathematics. After only four years, we have found that in the 10 year period following this project, the project will meet or exceed the number of students proposed to be impacted by the project participants. Nearly all participants are teaching in federally defined high needs schools or school districts, ultimately impacting historically marginalized and underserved students in STEM disciplines.

This project's significant results led to the establishment of a statewide partnership between The University of Alabama System comprising three universities (UA-Tuscaloosa Main Campus, UA-Huntsville, UA-Birmingham), Alabama State University, South Alabama University, and Jacksonville State University. The new partnership proposed and acquired a newly funded CS4ALL (Medium) NSF project which will produce up to 90 teacher candidates endorsed to teach CS following the pathway developed in this completed project. At the conclusion of the newly funded project, all partner institutions it is estimated could produce an additional 100-500 newly credentialed CS teachers in Alabama partner universities by 2030.

Overall, the project team developed new knowledge that has led to field dissemination, as well as impacts on STEM education, students, and teachers in Alabama.


Last Modified: 12/16/2021
Modified by: Jeremy S Zelkowski
